DT Article
TI TWO NEW SANDPERCHES (PERCIFORMES: PINGUIPEDIDAE: PARAPERCIS) FROM SOUTH
   CHINA SEA, BASED ON MORPHOLOGY AND DNA BARCODING.
AU Ho, Hsuan-Ching
   Chang, Chia-Hao
   Shao, Kwang-Tsao (chiahao0928@gmail.com) 
SO Raffles Bulletin of Zoology
VL 60
IS 1
PS 163-172
PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Two new cryptic sandperch species of the pinguipedid genus Parapercis
   are described from off southern Taiwan, northern South China Sea.
   Parapercis kentingensis n. sp., described from 25 specimens, is
   morphologically similar to P shaoi Randall, 2008. Parapercis
   rubromaculata n. sp., described from four specimens, is morphologically
   similar to P randalli Ho&Shao, 2010. The four species have sympatric
   distributions in southern Taiwan. Both new species differ from their
   congeners in colouration and a combination of other characters.
   Morphological evidence for establishing new species status is also
   supported by DNA barcoding.

   Taiwan.

TI A new Adamystis Cunliffe, 1957 species from Iran (Acari: Trombidiformes:
   Adamystidae).
AU Beyzavi, Gholamreza
   Ueckermann, Edward A. (UeckermannE@arc.agric.za) 
   Ostovan, Hadi
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 27-30
PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Adamystidae is described, Adamystis iranoturanianensis
   sp. nov. These mites were collected from soil, humus and litter in the
   southern parts of the Kamfiruz Region in Fars, Iran. This family
   comprises 16 species including the new species described herein. The new
   species differs from the other members of this family by: the fused,
   punctate and reticulate endopodal shield; possessing two pairs of plates
   in the genital region; and the unique coxal formula 1-3-2-2. This is the
   first record of this family from Iran.
C1 Ueckermann, Edward A.; ARC Plant Protect Res Inst, Private Bag X134,
   Pretoria, ZA-0121, South Africa, South Africa.

   western Iran.

LA English

AB A new mite species, Adamystis alvandicus sp. nov., is described and
   illustrated from female specimens collected from soil under Spiny
   Hawthorn trees, Crataegus aronia (L.) (Rosaceae), near Alvand Mountain
   in Hamedan province, Iran. The new species is distinguished by lacking
   lens like structures, having one pair of eyes, a smooth dorsal shield
   and coxae I IV 2-3-3-2. All other Adamystis have three setae on
   coxisternae IV.

AB Calyptostoma gorganica Saboori&Soukhtsaraii sp. nov. (Acari:
   Calyptostomatidae) is described and illustrated from larvae
   ectoparasitic on Limonia caucasica Lackschewitz, 1940 (Diptera:
   Tipulidae) from Shast Kalateh forest, Gorgan, Golestan Province,
   Northern Iran. It is the first report of the representatives of the
   superfamily Calyptostomatoidea from the Middle East. Calyptostoma
   latiseta and C. simplexa are not synonymous with C. velutinum. A key to
   larval species of Calyptostoma of the world is presented.

AU Khanjani, Mohammad (mkhanjani@gmail.com)

VL 17

PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A new mite species, Ledermuelleriopsis dogani sp. nov. is described and
   illustrated based on material collected from Euonymus japonicus Thunberg
   (Celastraceae) and Pinus pinea L. (Pinaceae) at Marvdasht, Fars
   province. The dorsal setae of the new species are clavate-spinose and
   the coxisternal shields are smooth. A key to all known world species of
   the genus is given.

DT Article
TI Eutarsopolipus jacobi sp nov (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral parasite
   of Diplocheila impressicollis (Coleoptera: Carabidae) from Michigan,
   USA.
AU Husband, Robert W. (husbandadrian@aol.com) 
   Husband, David O.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 74-82
PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Eutarsopolipus jacobi sp. nov. (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral
   parasite of Diplocheila impressicollis Dejean (Coleoptera: Carabidae),
   is described from Washtenaw and Huron Counties, Michigan, U.S.A.
   Relationships with 13 previously described species in the myzus group of
   Eutarsopolipus are discussed and keys are provided to six species in the
   myzus group in the Western Hemisphere. This is the first record of a
   species in the myzus group parasitizing the carabid genus Diplocheila in
   the Western Hemisphere.
C1 Husband, Robert W.; Adrian Coll, Dept Biol, Adrian, MI, 49221, USA, USA.

TI Eutarsopolipus osunaharae sp nov (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral
   parasite of Diplocheila zeelandica (Redtenbacher) (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae) from Japan.
AU Husband, Robert W. (husbandadrian@aol.com) 
   Kurosa, Kazuyoshi
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 83-90
PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Eutarsopolipus osunaharae sp. nov. (Acari: Podapolipidae), subelytral
   parasite of Diplocheila zeelandica (Redtenbacher) (Coleoptera:
   Carabidae), is described from three localities in Japan. The
   relationships with seven previously described species in the pterostichi
   group of Eutarsopolipus are discussed and keys are provided to species
   in the pterostichi group. This is the first record of Eutarsopolipus in
   the pterostichi group in Japan and the first record of a species in this
   group parasitizing the carabid genus Diplocheila.

DT Article
TI Oribatid mites of the genera Epilohmannia, Furcoppia and Unguizetes
   (Acari: Oribatida: Epilohmanniidae; Astegistidae; Mochlozetidae) from
   Vietnam.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, Alexander E.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 91-105
PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Three new species of oribatid mites, Epilohmannia crassisetosa sp. nov.,
   Furcoppia cattienica sp. nov. and Unguizetes asiaticus sp. nov., are
   described. All three are from dark loamy soil of Logerstroemia forest in
   the Cat Tien National Park (southern Vietnam). The species E. pallida
   pacifica Aoki and U. sphaerula (Berlese) are newly recorded in Vietnam.
   Diagnostic keys to the Vietnamese species of Epilohmannia and Unguizetes
   are presented. Mochlozetes atypicus Mahunka, 1982 is reinstated in the
   genus Unguizetes.

   record].

DT Article
TI A new species of fossil oribatid mite (Acariformes, Oribatida,
   Trhypochthoniidae) from the Lower Cretaceous amber of San Just (Teruel
   Province, Spain).
AU Arillo, Antonio (aarillo@terra.es) 
   Subias, Luis S.
   Shtanchaeva, Umukusum
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 17
IS 1
PS 106-112
PD Feb 29 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new fossil species, Trhypochthonius lopezvallei sp. nov.
   (Trhypochthoniidae), is described based on one specimen preserved in
   amber from the San Just outcrop (Teruel Province, Spain) believed to be
   Albian in age. A comparison with Recent and fossil Trhypochthoniidae is
   given. A new name, Sachalinbates, is proposed to replace Sachalinella (a
   fossil oribatid genus described from Sakhalin Paleocene amber) which is
   preoccupied.

   Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI Chalcosicya maya n. sp, a new Mexican species (Coleoptera:
   Chrysomelidae: Eumolpinae) and its implications for morphology and
   biogeography.
AU Flowers, R. Wills (rlowers7@earthlink.net) 
SO Insecta Mundi
VL 0209
PS 1-9
PD February 29 2012
PY 2012
UR http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0209Flowers.pdf
AW http://centerforsystematicentomology.org/insectamundi/0209Flowers.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Chalcosicya maya, new species, (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Eumolpinae)
   is described and the species key of Blake (1951) is modiied to
   accommodate it. This is the first known mainland species of this
   previously Antillean genus. Sclerotized rods in the apical segment of
   the ovipositor of Chalcosicya Blake and related genera are shown to be
   useful systematic characters within the eumolpine tribe Adoxini.
   Relationships with other genera suggest that Chalcosicya belongs to a
   clade derived from ancestors with a western Tethyian distribution.
C1 Flowers, R. Wills; Center for Biological Control, Floirda A&M
   University, Tallahassee, FL 32307, USA, USA.
EM rlowers7@earthlink.net
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology

   morphology; Evolution; Zoogeography; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   Neotropical region; North America; Central America

   America /  / ] [West Indies /  / systematics; phylogeny & biogeography].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804031760
DT Article
TI A revision of the Palaeocorystoidea and the phylogeny of raninoidian
   crabs (Crustacea, Decapoda, Brachyura, Podotremata).
AU van Bakel, Barry W.M. (barryvanbakel@gmail.com) 
   Guinot, Daniele
   Artal, Pedro
   Fraaije, Rene H.B.
   Jagt, John W.M.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3215
PS 1-216
PD 29 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03215p216.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03215p216.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Abundant fossil material of extinct brachyurans has revealed
   morphological details hitherto rarely used in palaeontological studies.
   Detailed comparisons between extant and extinct material have been
   carried out, with an emphasis on thoracic sternum, abdomen and
   appendages. Documented for the first time is the unique character of
   Raninoidea De Haan, 1839, their 'gymnopleurity', which is not found in
   their predecessors, the Palaeocorystidae Lorenthey in Lorenthey &
   Beurlen, 1929. Palaeocorystidae, together with four other families
   (Camarocarcinidae Feldmann, Li & Schweitzer, 2008; Cenomanocarcinidae
   Guinot, Vega & Van Bakel, 2008; Necrocarcinidae Forster, 1968 emend.;
   and Orithopsidae Schweitzer, Feldmann, Fam, Hessin, Hetrick, Nyborg &
   Ross, 2003a emend.), is assigned here to the superfamily
   Palaeocorystoidea, of similar rank to Raninoidea. Both Raninoidea and
   Palaeocorystoidea are afforded a subsection rank and referred to as
   subsection Raninoidia De Haan, 1839 emend. New or emended diagnoses are
   provided for all higher taxonomic levels, and all members of Raninoidia
   are listed in an appendix. A unique abdominal holding structure, the
   double peg, is described for the first time. Its gradual evolution is
   documented and the phylogenetic implications are discussed. Comparative
   morphology of the thoracic sternum, abdominal holding structures, the
   sternum- pterygostome configuration, respiratory physiology and
   spermathecae, all reveal polarities of the raninoidian clade. The
   configuration of the sternum with the pterygostome, which is related to
   body strength and respiratory physiological efficiency, differs
   significantly between the two superfamilies, Raninoidea showing a
   derived condition. An evolutionary lineage, leading from
   Palaeocorystidae, via Lyreididae to Raninidae is recognised, and an
   intermediate form, Marylyreidus punctatus n. comb., is discussed.
   Several hitherto unknown structures in extant raninoids, an obstruction
   system for the abdomen and a telson protection valve, are documented.
   The cryptic spermathecal apertures of raninoids, so far barely
   understood, are re-examined and compared to those of palaeocorystoids.
   The phylogeny of Podotremata, often debated in the recent literature, is
   discussed anew on the basis of these observations. A position of
   Raninoidea within Eubrachyura, recently claimed by several authors,
   cannot be maintained, an observation supported by documentation of the
   basal condition of Raninoidia. A new basal lyreidid clade,
   Marylyreidinae n. subfam., is erected, whereas new genera and species
   include Antonioranina n. gen. (Cyrtorhininae), Bournelyreidus teodorii
   n. gen., n. sp. (Lyreidinae), Cenocorystes bretoni n. sp.
   (Palaeocorystidae), Cenomanocarcinus cantabricus n. sp.
   (Cenomanocarcinidae), Eosymethis aragonensis n. gen., n. sp.
   (Symethinae), Eucorystes iserbyti n. sp., Eucorystes navarrensis n. sp.
   (both Palaeocorystidae), Ferroranina tamilnadu n. gen., n. sp.
   (Palaeocorystidae), Joeranina gaspari n. gen., n. sp.
   (Palaeocorystidae), Marylyreidus n. gen. (Marylyreidinae n. subfam.),
   Paranecrocarcinus balla n. sp. (Paranecrocarcininae), Symethoides
   monmouthorum n. gen., n. sp. (Symethinae) and Vegaranina n. gen.
   (Ranininae). Several raninoid and palaeocorystoid genera are revised,
   and emended diagnoses given.
C1 van Bakel, Barry W.M.; Oertijdmuseum de Groene Poort, Bosscheweg 80,
   NL-5283 WB Boxtel, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM barryvanbakel@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Paleontology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Unavailable name;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Documentation; Publications;
   General morphology; Evolution; Land zones; Nearctic region; Oriental
   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; India; Europe; North America;
   USA; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene; Mesozoic
DE Antonioranina; Eosymethis [Eocene /  / New genus]. 
   Bournelyreidus; Ferroranina; Joeranina; Marylyreidus; Vegaranina
   [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Cenocorystes bretoni; Eucorystes iserbyti; Paranecrocarcinus balla;
   Raninella teodorii [France /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Cenomanocarcinus cantabricus; Eucorystes navarrensis; Joeranina gaspari
   [Spain /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Eosymethis aragonensis [Spain /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
   Ferroranina tamilnadu [Tamil Nadu /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ].

   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Hasaracancer renfroae - (Stenzel 1945) (Decapoda): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Necrocarcinus, p. 58; Fossil]. 
   Brachyura (Reptantia): [Classification, Extant taxa only, p. 7]. 
   Antonioranina (Brachyura): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Cyrtorhininae, Type
   species Cyrtorhina globosa Beschin, Busulini, De Angeli & Tessier 1988,
   p. 108, Eocene; Fossil]. 
   Antonioranina fusseli - (Blow & Manning 1996) (Brachyura): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Cyrtorhina, p. 108; Fossil]. 
   Antonioranina globosa - (Beschin, Busulini, De Angeli & Tessier 1988)
   (Brachyura): [Comb nov, Transferred from Cyrtorhina, p. 108; Fossil]. 
   Antonioranina oblonga - (Beschin, Busulini, De Angeli & Tessier 1988)
   (Brachyura): [Comb nov, Transferred from Cyrtorhina, p. 108; Fossil]. 
   Antonioranina ripacurtae - (Artal & Castillo 2005) (Brachyura): [Comb

   Bournelyreidus (Brachyura): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Lyreidinae, Type
   species Hemioon eysunesensis Collins & Wienberg Rasmussen 1992, p. 78,
   Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Bournelyreidus carlilensis - (Feldmann & Maxey 1980) (Brachyura): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Raninella, p. 79; Fossil]. 
   Bournelyreidus eysunesensis - (Collins & Wienberg Rasmussen 1992)
   (Brachyura): [Comb nov, Transferred from Hemioon, p. 79; Fossil]. 
   Bournelyreidus laevis - (Schlueter in von der Marck & Schlueter 1868)
   (Brachyura): [Comb nov, Transferred from Palaeocorystes, p. 80; Fossil].
   
   Bournelyreidus manningi - (Bishop & Williams 2000) (Brachyura): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Raninella, p. 78; Fossil]. 
   Bournelyreidus tridens - (Roberts 1962) (Brachyura): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Raninella, p. 83; Fossil]. 
   Bournelyreidus? oaheensis - (Bishop 1978) (Brachyura): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Raninella, p. 81; Fossil]. 
   Camarocarcinidae - Feldmann, Li & Schweitzer 2008 (Brachyura): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 45; Fossil]. 
   Campylostoma - Bell 1858 (Brachyura): [Taxonomic position, P. 57;
   Fossil]. 
   Campylostoma matutiforme - Bell 1858 (Brachyura): [Redescription, P. 57;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Catalogue of the type-species of the genera of the Cerambycidae,
   Disteniidae, Oxypeltidae and Vesperidae (Coleoptera) of the Neotropical
   Region.
AU Monne, Miguel A. (monne@uol.com.br) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3213
PS 1-183
PD 29 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03213p183.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03213p183.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The present list includes all available names, both valid and invalid,
   and the type-species of the genera and subgenera of Cerambycidae,
   Disteniidae, Oxypeltidae and Vesperidae (Coleoptera) of the Neotropical
   Region. Two new family-group names are proposed: Neoibidionini
   (type-genus: Neoibidion, a replacement name for Ibidion
   Audinet-Serville, 1834, ju- nior homonymy of Ibidion Gory, 1833) for
   Ibidionini Thomson, 1861 and Proholopterini (type-genus Proholopterus, a
   replacement name for Holopterus Blanchard, 1851, junior homonymy of
   Holopterus Brehm, 1845) for Holopterini La- cordaire, 1868. Oideterus
   Thomson, 1857a:15 is revalidated with the type-species, Oideterus
   buquetii Thomson, 1857 (by monotypy). Udeterus Thomson, 1858b:515 is a
   junior synonym of Oideterus Thomson, 1857. Acanthocornis Monne & Monne,
   2011 (Prioninae, Meroscelisini) is a new synonym of Hyleoza Galileo,
   1987 and Acanthocornis flavus Monne & Monne, 2011 = Hyleoza confusa
   Tavakilian & Galileo, 1991. The genus Acanthocornis Monne & Monne, 2011
   was erro- neously described in the tribe Anacolini. Acanthinodera Hope,
   1834 is considered a nomen protectum and hereafter used as valid genus
   name. Amallopodes Lequien, 1833 is a nomen oblitum consequently invalid
   name. Hephaestion (?) zikani Melzer, 1923 is designated as the
   type-species of Parahephaestion Melzer, 1930; Corynellus mimulus Bates,
   1885 as the type-species of Corynellus Bates, 1885; Cosmius ochraceus
   Perty, 1832 as the type-species of Cosmius Perty, 1832 non Cosmius
   Dumeril, 1806, Diptera, and Alampyris nigra Bates, 1881 as the
   type-species of Alampyris Bates, 1881.
C1 Monne, Miguel A.; Departamento de Entomologia, Museu Nacional,
   Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Quinta da Boa Vista, Sao
   Cristovao, 20940-040, Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM monne@uol.com.br
SC Zoology

   Unavailable name; Taxonomy; Status; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones

   / ].

   Disteniidae (Cerambycidae).

DT Article
TI The Aleyrodidae (Hemiptera: Sternorrhyncha) of the Canary Islands with
   special reference to Aleyrodes, Siphoninus, and the challenges of
   puparial morphology in Bemisia.
AU Hernandez-Suarez, Estrella (ehernand@icia.es) 
   Martin, Jon H.
   Gill, Raymond J.
   Bedford, Ian D.
   Malumphy, Christopher P.
   Betancort, J. Alfredo Reyes
   Carnero, Aurelio
SO Zootaxa
VL 3212
PS 1-76
PD 29 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03212p076.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03212p076.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB The whitefly fauna of the Canary Islands (Spain) comprises 21 named
   species distributed amongst 12 genera, including four species described
   here [long dash] Aleyrodes bencomiae Hernandez-Suarez and Martin sp.
   nov., Aleyrodes laurisilvae Hernandez-Suarez and Martin sp. nov.,
   Bemisia euphorbiarum Hernandez-Suarez and Malumphy sp. nov. and Bemisia
   reyesi Hernandez-Suarez and Martin sp. nov. Nomenclatural changes
   comprise the four new species, one revalidated species (Siphoninus
   finitimus Silvestri stat. rev.), and two revised synonymies (Siphoninus
   phillyreae multitubulatus Goux becomes a junior synonym of S. finitimus
   Silvestri and is removed from synonymy with S. phillyreae (Haliday), and
   the genus Bemisiella Danzig becomes a junior synonym of Asterobemisia
   Trehan; both the latter genera are removed from synonymy with Bemisia
   Quaintance & Baker). Also, we have provided detailed discussions and
   illustrations of eight distinctive puparial forms of the Bemisia afer
   complex with scanning electron microphotographs (SEMs), line drawings
   and habitus photographs. In addition to the taxa described and discussed
   here, there are two new records for the Canary Islands, Dialeurodes
   citri (Ashmead) and Paraleyrodes minei Iaccarino. For each of the
   species already known and named prior to this study we include a brief
   account including its world distribution, its host-plant range in the
   Canary Islands, and further notes on host range beyond the Canaries. The
   general puparial morphology of each species is illustrated with a
   combination of line-drawings and habitus photographs. Three appendices
   are provided[long dash]a check list of Canarian whiteflies, a table of
   host plants of whiteflies in the Canary Islands, and lists of examined
   material for the whitefly species already known and named prior to our
   study.
C1 Hernandez-Suarez, Estrella; Department of Proteccion Vegetal, Instituto
   Canario de Investigaciones Agrarias, P.B. 60, E38200 - La Laguna,
   Tenerife, Islas Canarias, Spain, Spain.
EM ehernand@icia.es
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts;
   Land zones; Oceanic islands; Atlantic Ocean islands

   plant host].

   berthelotii / ] [ / Euphorbia lamarckii var. wildpretti / ] [ /

   [Canary Islands /  / New species from plant host].

   [Canary Islands /  / New species from plant host].

   [Canary Islands /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Sternorrhyncha,
   Aleyrodoidea
OR Aleyrodes bencomiae - Hernandez-Suarez & Martin 2012 (Aleyrodoidea): [Sp
   nov, Canary Islands, Parasite of Bencomia caudata (Plant), p. 13;
   Parasite]. 
   Aleyrodes laurisilvae - Hernandez-Suarez & Martin 2012 (Aleyrodoidea):
   [Sp nov, Canary Islands, Parasite of Canarina canariensis (Plant), p.
   12; Parasite]. 
   Aleyrodidae (Aleyrodoidea): [Key to genera, Canary Islands, Puparia, p.
   7; Parasite]. 
   Asterobemisia - Trehan 1940 (Aleyrodoidea): [Syn nov, Bemisiella Danzig
   1966, p. 15; Removal from synonymy, With Bemisia Quaintance & Baker
   1914, p. 15]. 
   Bemisia - Quaintance & Baker 1914 (Aleyrodoidea): [Removal from
   synonymy, Asterobemisia Trehan 1940, p. 15; Removal from synonymy,
   Bemisiella Danzig 1966, p. 15]. 
   Bemisia euphorbiarum - Hernandez-Suarez & Malumphy 2012 (Aleyrodoidea):
   [Sp nov, Canary Islands, Parasite of Euphorbia (Plant), p. 20;
   Parasite].

   Canary Islands, Parasite of Hypericum reflexum (Plant), p. 23;
   Parasite]. 
   Bemisiella - Danzig 1966 (Aleyrodoidea): [Removal from synonymy, With

   Dialeurodes citri (Aleyrodoidea): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Paraleyrodes minei (Aleyrodoidea): [Parasite; New record].

   Siphoninus phillyreae multitubulatus Goux 1949, p. 27; Removal from

   Siphoninus phillyreae - (Haliday 1835) (Aleyrodoidea): [Removal from
   synonymy, Siphoninus finitimus Silvestri 1915, p. 29; Removal from
   synonymy, Siphoninus phillyreae multitubulatus Goux 1949, p. 29]. 
   Siphoninus phillyreae multitubulatus - Goux 1949 (Aleyrodoidea):
   [Removal from synonymy, With Siphoninus phillyreae (Haliday 1835), p.
   29].

DT Article
TI Biodiversity Quadrupled - Revision of Easter Island and Salas y Gomez
   Bivalves.
AU Raines, Bret (rainesbk@yahoo.com) 
   Huber, Markus
SO Zootaxa
VL 3217
PS 1-106
PD 29 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03217p106.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03217p106.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Seventy-one bivalve species, including fifteen new species living in the
   waters of Easter and Salas y Gomez Islands are herein described:
   Nuculana (s.l.) anakena sp. nov., Lasaea eastera sp. nov., Borniola
   pasca sp. nov., Hyalokellia tahaia sp. nov., Tellimya pauciradiata sp.
   nov., Tellimya tahaia sp. nov., Thecodonta rainesi sp. nov.,
   Acrosterigma triangulare sp. nov., Herouvalia rapanui sp. nov., Moerella
   laperousea sp. nov., Abranda lamprelli sp. nov., Timoclea keegani sp.
   nov., Hyphantosoma crassum sp. nov., Hyphantosoma tenue sp. nov. and
   Austroneaera eastera sp. nov. Illustrated for the first time is the type
   material of Tindaria salaria Dall, 1908. Results of this study also
   revise previously accepted levels of endemicity as well as species
   affiliation with other biogeographical areas.
C1 Raines, Bret; Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, California,
   USA, USA.
EM rainesbk@yahoo.com
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Ecology; Distribution within habitat;
   Zoogeography; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean; Geological time periods
DE Abranda lamprelli; Acrosterigma triangulare; Austroneaera eastera;
   Hyalokellia tahaia; Hyphantosoma crassum; Hyphantosoma tenue; Lasaea
   eastera; Moerella laperousea; Nuculana anakena; Tellimya pauciradiata;
   Thecodonta rainesi; Timoclea keegani [South Pacific /  / New species]. 
   Bivalvia [Community structure / Biodiversity / new record; systematics]
   [Vertical distribution /  / ] [Zoogeography / Endemicity levels & faunal
   affinities / ] [South Pacific / Easter Island & Sala y Gomez / biology;
   distribution]. 
   Borniola pasca; Herouvalia rapanui; Tellimya tahaia [South Pacific /  /

DT Article
TI CHIGGER MITES (ACARI: TROMBICULIDAE) OF TURKEY.
AU Stekolnikov, Alexander (acari@zin.ru) 
   Daniel, Milan
SO Zootaxa
VL 3216
PS 1-104
PD 29 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03216p104.pdf
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03216p104.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Chigger mites of Turkey were studied on the base of three expeditions
   (in 1969, 1998, and 2009) and revision of all previously published data
   on this subject. In total, 43 species from 14 genera parasitizing
   rodents, soricomorphs, and reptiles in Turkey are considered, 37 of
   which are identified exactly. Eight new species from the Western and
   Central Taurus Mts are described: Xinjiangsha lyciaensis sp. nov.,
   Kepkatrombicula ciliciensis sp. nov., K. taurensis sp. nov.,
   Neotrombicula kizlarsivrisiensis sp. nov., N. kolebinovae sp. nov., N.
   bolkarensis sp. nov., Miyatrombicula attaliaensis sp. nov., and
   Cheladonta deserticola sp. nov. Twelve species were recorded in Turkey
   for the first time; moreover, some new records from other countries were
   reported (four species were for the first time recorded in Russia, and
   by one species were re- corded in Armenia, Azerbaijan, Israel,
   Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan). For seven chigger genera (Xinjiangsha Wen
   and Shao, 1984, Hirsutiella Schluger and Vysotzkaya, 1970, Lacertacarus
   Schluger and Vasilieva, 1977, Miyatrombicula Sa- sa, Kawashima and
   Egashira, 1952, Brunehaldia Vercammen-Grandjean, 1960, Cheladonta
   Lipovsky, Crossley and Loomis, 1955, and Matacarus Vercammen-Grandjean,
   1956), the complete lists of species in the world fauna are provid- ed.
   Four new synonyms and 18 new combinations were established: Xinjiangsha
   Wen and Shao, 1984 (= Aboriginesia Kudryashova, 1993, syn. nov.),
   Neotrombicula vulgaris (Schluger, 1955) (= Trombicula acomys Radford,
   1957, syn. nov.), Brunehaldia brunehaldi (Vercammen-Grandjean, 1956) (=
   Eushoengastia (Brunehaldia) aegypti Vercammen- Grandjean and Kolebinova,
   1966, syn. nov.), Brunehaldia curtinae (Kepka, 1966) (= Eushoengastia
   (Brunehaldia) lucida (Schluger, 1966), syn. nov.), Xinjiangsha blanci
   (Vercammen-Grandjean, 1956), comb. nov., X. danieli (Kolebinova, 1974),
   comb. nov., X. feideri (Daniel and Brelih, 1959), comb. nov., X. galla
   (Kolebinova, 1970), comb. nov., X. iberica (Schluger, 1957), comb. nov.,
   X. imlilica (Brown, 2008), comb. nov., X. ludmilae (Kovacik and Kaluz,
   2010), comb. nov., X. montana (Kudryashova, 1965), comb. nov., X.
   monticola (Kolebinova, 1974), comb. nov., X. obuchi (Kovacik and Ka-
   luz, 2010), comb. nov., X. raissae (Hushcha and Kharadov, 1987), comb.
   nov., X. talpae (Kolebinova, 1977), comb. nov., X. tarda (Schluger,
   1957), comb. nov., X. theodori (Hushcha, 1986), comb. nov., X.
   tshatkalica (Hushcha and Kharadov, 1985), comb. nov., X. variabilis
   (Schluger and Vshivkov, 1967), comb. nov., Brunehaldia spalaxia
   (Radford, 1957), comb. nov., and Matacarus demrei (Kepka, 1962), comb.
   nov. A key to genera and species of chigger mites from Turkey is
   provided.

   Sciences, Universitetskaya quay 1, St. Petersburg 199034, Russia,
   Russia.

DT Article
TI Redescription of two ghost shrimps (Decapoda: Axiidea: Callianassidae)
   from the Middle Miocene of the Central Paratethys: systematics,
   intraspecific variation, and in situ preservation.
AU Hyzny, Matus (hyzny.matus@gmail.com) 
   Hudackova, Natalia
SO Zootaxa
VL 3210
PS 1-25
PD 28 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3210.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03210p025.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A redescription of two Middle Miocene burrowing ghost shrimps of the
   Central Paratethys, Callianassa brocchii Lorenthey, 1897 and Callianassa
   pseudorakosensis Lorenthey in Lorenthey & Beurlen, 1929, is provided.
   Material forming the basis of this study comes from the Studienka
   Formation (lower 'Sarmatian', Serravallian) of the Slovak part of the
   Vienna Basin and exhibits preservation allowing reassignment of the
   studied taxa to the genera Neocallichirus Sakai, 1988 and Eucalliax
   Manning & Felder, 1991 respectively. The major cheliped of both species
   exhibits two distinct morphotypes interpreted herein as possible sexual
   dimorpism. Several specimens of both taxa are preserved within the tube
   structures and are interpreted as in situ preservation within the
   burrows. Type material of both studied taxa and additional collections
   from the roughly coeval strata of Hungary and Austria were also studied.
C1 Hyzny, Matus; Department of Geology and Paleontology, Faculty of Natural
   Sciences, Comenius University, Mlynska dolina G1, 842 15 Bratislava,
   Slovakia, Slovakia.
EM hyzny.matus@gmail.com
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology; Paleontology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Description; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; General morphology; Appendages; Biramous
   limbs; Reproduction; Ecology; Fossilization; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Eucalliax pseudorakosensis; Neocallichirus brocchii [Chelipeds /
   Cheliped morphology / ] [Sex differences /  / ] [State of preservation /
   Preservation within burrows / ] [Slovakia / Vienna Basin / ] [Miocene /
   Middle Miocene / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Anomura
OR Callianassa brocchii - Lorenthey 1897 (Anomura): [Referred to,
   Neocallichirus, p. 4]. 
   Callianassa pseudorakosensis - Lorenthey in Lorenthey & Beurlen 1929
   (Anomura): [Referred to, Eucalliax, p. 14]. 
   Eucalliax pseudorakosensis - (Lorenthey in Lorenthey & Beurlen 1929)
   (Anomura): [Emended diagnosis, P. 14; Redescription, P. 14; Comb nov,
   Transferred from Callianassa, p. 14; Fossil]. 
   Neocallichirus brocchii - (Lorenthey 1897) (Anomura): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 5; Redescription, P. 5; Comb nov, Transferred from
   Callianassa, p. 4; Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14804031558
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR14804031560
DT Article
TI New Uropodina (Acari: Mesostigmata) from California, USA.
AU Kontschan, Jeno (kontscha@zool.nhmus.hu) 
   Stary, Josef
SO Zootaxa
VL 3210
PS 26-38
PD 28 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3210.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03210p038.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Jedediella horneri gen. nov., sp. nov. is described on the basis of two
   females and four males collected in California, USA. The new genus is
   unusual among uropodine mites by the shape and length of chelicerae. A
   previously described species of uropodine of uncertain taxonomic
   placement, Discourella sellnicki Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nicol, 1969, is
   transferred to the new genus as Jedediella sellnicki (Hirschmann &
   Zirngiebl-Nicol, 1969) comb. nov. Two new Trachytes species (T. axe sp.
   nov. and T. californica sp. nov.) are described and illustrated
   accompanied with a new key and notes to the Trachytes species of North
   America.
C1 Kontschan, Jeno; Hungarian Natural History Museum, H-1088 Budapest,
   Baross u. 13, Hungary, Hungary.
EM kontscha@zool.nhmus.hu
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Key; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Jedediella horneri; Trachytes axe; Trachytes californica [California / 
   / New species]. 
   Trachytes [North America /  / Key to species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Discourella sellnicki - Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nichol 1969 (Acari):
   [Referred to, New genus Jedediella, p. 30]. 
   Jedediella (Acari): [Gen nov, Of cohort Uropodina, Type species
   Jedediella horneri, p. 26]. 
   Jedediella horneri (Acari): [Sp nov, California, P. 27]. 
   Jedediella sellnicki - (Hirschmann & Zirngiebl-Nichol 1969) (Acari):
   [Comb nov, Transferred from Discourella, p. 30]. 
   Trachytes - Michael 1894 (Acari): [Key to species, North America, P.
   37].

DT Article
TI On the taxonomic status of Chactas camposi Mello-Leitao, 1939
   (Scorpiones, Chactidae).
AU Ochoa, Jose A. (jaochoac2000@yahoo.com) 
   Pinto-da-Rocha, Ricardo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3210
PS 61-68
PD 28 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3210.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03210p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The true taxonomic status of the chactid scorpion Chactas camposi
   Mello-Leitao, 1939 from Ecuador is established based in the recently
   discovered holotype female, until now considered lost, at the Museu
   Nacional do Rio de Janeiro. In base on the analysis of the external
   morphology, we transfer this species to the genus Teuthraustes Simon,
   1878. A detailed redescription and diagnosis according to modern
   standards are provided. Teuthraustes camposi comb. n. is closely related
   with Teuthraustes whymperi (Pocock, 1893) from Ecuadorian provinces
   Pichincha and Cotopaxi.
C1 Ochoa, Jose A.; Departamento de Zoologia, Instituto de Biociencias,
   Universidade de Sao Paulo, Rua do Matao, travessa 14, 101, Sao Paulo,
   SP, 05508[long dash]900, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jaochoac2000@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Scorpiones
OR Chactas camposi - Mello-Leitao 1939 (Scorpiones): [Referred to,
   Teuthraustes, p. 63]. 
   Teuthraustes camposi - (Mello-Leitao 1939) (Scorpiones): [Emended
   diagnosis, P. 63; Redescription, P. 63; Comb nov, Transferred from
   Chactas, p. 63].

DT Article
TI Identification of Neotropical blow flies of the genus Calliphora
   Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera: Calliphoridae) with the description of a new
   species.
AU Whitworth, Terry (twhitworth@wsu.edu) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3209
PS 1-27
PD 28 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3209.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/f/zt03209p027.pdf
NT With contributions from: Rognes, K.
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A key to the six known species of Calliphora Robineau-Desvoidy (Diptera:
   Calliphoridae) from the Neotropical Region is given. Species
   distributions and key characters are discussed. Calliphora irazuana
   Townsend, 1908 is resurrected as a valid name for a species found in
   Central America and Mexico, stat. nov. Calliphora triseta sp. nov. is
   described from numerous specimens from Costa Rica, El Salvador and
   Mexico. Nominal species Calliphora nigra Mello, 1974 and Calliphora
   antojuanae Mariluis, 1982 are synonymized with Calliphora nigribasis
   Macquart, 1851, n. syn. An Appendix is provided that clarifies the
   status of the names Calliphora peruviana Robineau-Desvoidy, 1830,
   Lucilia peruviana Robineau- Desvoidy, 1830, and Calliphora peruviana
   Macquart, 1851.
C1 Whitworth, Terry; Department of Entomology, Washington State University,
   Pullman, WA 99164-6382, USA, USA.
EM twhitworth@wsu.edu

   Salvador /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804031576
DT Article
TI An extraordinary new genus and three new species of Acostemmini
   (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae: Deltocephalinae) from Madagascar with comments
   on the morphology and classification of the tribe.
AU Zahniser, J. (zahniser@illinois.edu) 
   Nielson, M.W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3209
PS 28-52
PD 28 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3209.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03209p052.pdf
LA English
U1 3
U2 4
AB The circumscription and morphological characterization of the
   deltocephaline tribe Acostemmini is revised based on discoveries of new
   and poorly known taxa from recent collections in Madagascar and from
   examination of the type specimens of Alocoelidia fulva Evans, Iturnoria
   insulana Evans, and Protonesis delegorguei Spinola. Alocoelidia Evans
   1954, Caelidioides Signoret 1880, Iturnoria Evans 1954, and Protonesis
   Spinola 1850 were previously placed in Coelidiinae but were later
   removed from the subfamily and until now have been unplaced to subfamily
   are placed here in Deltocephalinae: Acostemmini, new placement. A new
   genus and species, Ikelibeloha cristata gen. n., sp. n., are described
   that have an unusually modified structure of the head and a large,
   crested pronotum. Molecular data (28S, Histone H3 genes) were obtained
   for Ikelibeloha and Iturnoria, and analyzed with other members of
   Deltocephalinae. Results of the phylogenetic analyses show strong
   support for the monophyletic clade ((Acostemma, Eryapus), (Ikelibeloha,
   Iturnoria)) and thus a relationship between previously described
   Acostemmini, Ikelibeloha, and Iturnoria has strong statistical support,
   and a close relationship is inferred between these and the
   morphologically similar Alocoelidia, Caelidioides, and Protonesis. Two
   new species of Alocoelidia, A. maurae sp. n. and A. chasei sp. n. are
   described, and the genus is redescribed. The male genitalia of
   Caelidioides tristis (Signoret), Iturnoria insulana, Alocoelidia fulva,
   and Acostemella rubra Evans are illustrated and described for the first
   time. The female genitalia of A. fulva, C. tristis and I. insulana are
   described and the first and second valvulae of C. tristis are
   illustrated. The habitus and face of Protonesis delegorguei are
   illustrated and the genus is redescribed. The characters traditionally
   used to define Acostemmini are reviewed with notes on their known
   degrees of variation, and characters that differentiate Acostemmini from
   the closely related tribe Stegelytrini are discussed. The type of
   Malagasiella minima Evans was also examined, and Malagasiella Evans,
   1954 is considered a junior synonym of Doratulina Melichar, 1903
   (Deltocephalinae: Stenometopiini), syn. n. giving the new combination
   Doratulina minima (Evans) comb. n.
C1 Zahniser, J.; Illinois Natural History Survey, Prairie Research
   Institute, University of Illinois at Urbana/Champaign, 1816 S. Oak St.,
   Champaign, IL 61820, USA, USA.
EM zahniser@illinois.edu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; General morphology; Evolution; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Acostemmini [General morphology /  / systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Alocoelidia chasei; Alocoelidia maurae; Ikelibeloha cristata [Madagascar
   /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hemiptera, Homoptera, Auchenorrhyncha,
   Cicadelloidea, Cicadellidae
OR Acostemella rubra - Evans 1954 (Cicadellidae): [First time described,
   Male genitalia, p. 49; First time figured, Male genitalia, p. 48]. 
   Acostemmini (Cicadellidae). 
   Alocoelidia - Evans 1954 (Cicadellidae): [Redescription, P. 36; Referred
   to, Deltocephalinae, Acostemmini from Coelidiinae, p. 36]. 
   Alocoelidia chasei (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 40]. 
   Alocoelidia fulva - Evans 1954 (Cicadellidae): [First time described,
   Male genitalia, p. 37; First time figured, Male genitalia, p. 38]. 
   Alocoelidia maurae (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 38]. 
   Caelidioides - Signoret 1880 (Cicadellidae): [Referred to,
   Deltocephalinae, Acostemmini from Coelidiinae, p. 40]. 
   Caelidioides tristis - (Signoret 1880) (Cicadellidae): [First time
   described, Male genitalia, p. 43; First time figured, Male genitalia, p.
   42]. 
   Doratulina - Melichar 1903 (Cicadellidae): [Syn nov, Malagasiella Evans
   1954, p. 49]. 
   Doratulina minima - (Evans 1954) (Cicadellidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Malagasiella, p. 49]. 
   Ikelibeloha (Cicadellidae): [Gen nov, Of tribe Acostemmini, Type species
   Ikelibeloha cristata, p. 33]. 
   Ikelibeloha cristata (Cicadellidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 35]. 
   Iturnoria - Evans 1954 (Cicadellidae): [Referred to, Deltocephalinae,
   Acostemmini from Coelidiinae, p. 45]. 
   Iturnoria insulana - Evans 1954 (Cicadellidae): [First time described,
   Male genitalia, p. 47; First time figured, Male genitalia, p. 46]. 
   Malagasiella minima - Evans 1954 (Cicadellidae): [Referred to,
   Doratulina, p. 49]. 
   Protonesis - Spinola 1850 (Cicadellidae): [Referred to, Deltocephalinae,
   Acostemmini from Coelidiinae, p. 44]. 
DI 10.11646/zootaxa.3209.1.2
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14804031576

PT J
AN ZOOR14804031429
DT Article
TI The masked water snakes of the genus Homalopsis Kuhl & van Hasselt, 1822
   (Squamata, Serpentes, Homalopsidae), with the description of a new
   species.
AU Murphy, John C. (fordonia1@comcast.net) 
   Voris, Harold K.
   Murthy, B.H.C.K.
   Traub, Joshua
   Cumberbatch, Christina
SO Zootaxa
VL 3208
PS 1-26
PD 27 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3208.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03208p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Masked water snakes of the genus Homalopsis are abundant in the wetlands
   of Southeastern Asia. Currently, two species are recognized, the
   widespread H. buccata Linnaeus and the Mekong drainage endemic H.
   nigroventralis Deuve. On the basis of morphology we resurrect H.
   hardwickii Gray and H. semizonata Blyth and describe a new species from
   Indochina. We establish a neotype for Coluber buccatus Linnaeus and
   examine the status of other names associated with this species.
   Homalopsis species can be distinguished from each other on the basis of
   dorsal scale row counts, the scales in the ocular ring, and other head
   scale architecture. The new species, Homalopsis mereljcoxi, is
   distinguished from all others by its one postocular and one
   postsubocular scale, and a higher dorsal scale row count (40[long
   dash]47 scale rows at midbody) that are reduced to more than 30 scale
   rows at the body's posterior. The new species is heavily exploited for
   the skin trade at Tonle Sap, Cambodia. Homalopsis likely contains other
   cryptic species that have evolved in the changing aquatic habitats of
   Southeast Asia. A key to the species of Homalopsis is provided.
C1 Murphy, John C.; Division of Amphibians and Reptiles, Field Museum of
   Natural History, 1400 S. Lake Shore Drive, Chicago, IL 60605, USA, USA.
EM fordonia1@comcast.net
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Diagnosis;
   Description; Synonymy; Available name; Taxonomy; Key; Animals and man;
   Disturbance by man; Commercial activities; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Homalopsis [Trade in animals / Skin trade / Systematics] [Asia / South
   east / biology; distribution]. 
   Homalopsis mereljcoxi [Cambodia /  / New species] [Thailand /  / ]
   [Vietnam /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Serpentes, Colubridae
OR Coluber buccatus - Linnaeus 1758 (Colubridae): [Neotype designated, P.
   1]. 
   Coluber subalbidus - Gmelin 1789 (Colubridae): [Removal from synonymy,
   With Homalopsis buccata (Linnaeus 1758), p. 10; Nomen dubium, P. 10]. 
   Homalopsis - Kuhl & Hasselt 1822 (Colubridae): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 5; Key to species, P. 21]. 
   Homalopsis buccata - (Linnaeus 1758) (Colubridae): [Description,
   Neotype, p. 10; Removal from synonymy, Coluber subalbidus Gmelin 1789,
   p. 10; Removal from synonymy, Homalopsis semizonata Blyth 1855, p. 1]. 
   Homalopsis hardwickii - Gray 1842 (Colubridae): [Redescription,
   Holotype, p. 13]. 
   Homalopsis mereljcoxi (Colubridae): [Sp nov, Thailand, P. 13]. 
   Homalopsis semizonata - Blyth 1855 (Colubridae): [Redescription,
   Holotype, p. 20; Removal from synonymy, With Homalopsis buccata
   (Linnaeus 1758), p. 1].

TI First record of the genus Acrodactyla Haliday (Hymenoptera:
   Ichneumonidae: Pimplinae) from Vietnam, with descriptions of six new
   species.
AU Pham, Nhi Thi (ptnhi2@yahoo.com) 
   Broad, Gavin R.
   Matsumoto, Rikio
   Boehme, Wolfgang
SO Zootaxa

PS 40-53

LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Six new Acrodactyla species are described and illustrated from Vietnam
   based on the Ichneumonidae collection deposited at the Netherlands
   Centre for Biodiversity, Naturalis, Netherlands and the Osaka Museum of
   Natural History, Japan: A. maiphuquyi sp. nov., A. elongata sp. nov., A.
   shawi sp. nov and A. tami sp. nov. collected from Lao Cai Province at an
   elevation of 1,700[long dash]2,320 m a.s.l; A. lachryma sp. nov.
   collected from Chu Mom Ray NP, Kon Tum Province at an elevation of
   700[long dash]900 m a.s.l; and A. phuthoensis sp. nov. collected from
   Xuan Son NP, Phu Tho Province at an elevation of 350[long dash]400 m
   a.s.l. Acrodactyla maiphuquyi sp. nov., A. elongata sp. nov. and A. tami
   sp. nov. belong to the degener group; A. lachryma sp. nov., A.
   phuthoensis sp. nov. and A. shawi sp. nov. belong to the quadrisculpta
   group.

DT Article
TI Idahelops alpagutae (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae: Helopini): a new genus
   and species from the Aegean region of Turkey.
AU Keskin, Bekir (bekir.keskin.phd@gmail.com) 
   Nabozhenko, Maxim V.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3207
PS 63-67
PD 27 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3207.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/1/zt03207p067.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Idahelops alpagutae, a new genus and species, is described from Aegean
   region of Turkey (Balikesir and Izmir provinces). Idahelops belongs to
   the cylindrinotoid group of the subtribe Cylindrinotina. The genus is
   close to Armenohelops Nabozhenko, 2002, from which it differs in the
   presence of large granules on the elytral intervals, the epipleural
   carina raised and reaching the elytal apex (the apical part of the
   elytra of Armenohelops is sloping, without a horizontal platform), and
   the completely pubescent body (Armenohelops is without pubescence).
C1 Keskin, Bekir; Zoology Department, Biology Section, Ege University,
   Bornova-Izmir 35100, Turkey, Turkey.
EM bekir.keskin.phd@gmail.com
RI Nabozhenko, Maxim/M-6109-2014; Keskin, Bekir/A-3893-2016
OI Keskin, Bekir/0000-0002-6662-8736; Nabozhenko, Maxim/0000-0001-7914-7942
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia
DE Idahelops alpagutae [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tenebrionidae
OR Idahelops (Tenebrionidae): [Gen nov, Of subtribe Cylindrinotina, Type
   species Idahelops alpagutae, p. 63]. 
   Idahelops alpagutae (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 64].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804030737
DT Article
TI A revision of the subgenus Eurycercus (Eurycercus) Baird, 1843 emend.
   nov. (Cladocera: Eurycercidae) in the Holarctic with the description of
   a new species from Alaska.
AU Bekker, Eugeniya I. (evbekker@ya.ru) 
   Kotov, Alexey A.
   Taylor, Derek J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3206
PS 1-40
PD 24 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3206.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03206p040.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB Frey (1975) subdivided the genus Eurycercus Baird, 1843 (Cladocera:
   Eurycercidae) into three subgenera: E. (Eurycercus) s.str., E.
   (Bullatifrons) Frey, 1975 and E. (Teretifrons) Frey, 1975. We conducted
   a revision of the subgenera Eurycercus (Eurycercus) and E.
   (Bullatifrons) in the Holarctic based on the morphology of
   parthenogenetic females and a phylogeny of cytochrome c oxidase subunit
   I (COI ) sequences. The following six species are found to be valid: E.
   lamellatus (O. F. Muller, 1776); E. macracanthus Frey, 1973; E.
   pompholygodes Frey, 1975; E. microdontus Frey, 1978; E. longirostris
   Hann, 1982; E. nipponica Tanaka & Fujuta, 2002. The separation of E.
   vernalis Hann, 1982 from E. longirostris lacks morphological and genetic
   justification, so E. vernalis is a junior synonym of E. longirostris. A
   new species, E. beringi sp. nov., was found in several localities in
   Alaska, U.S.A. Its characters are intermediate between two subgenera
   sensu Frey (1975): a median keel is expressed, but only in the posterior
   portion of the carapace dorsum (while it is absent in E. (Bullatifrons)
   and passes through all the dorsum in Eurycercus s.str.); the dorsal head
   pores are located on the bubble-like projection (a character of the
   subgenus E (Bullatifrons), but the latter is sitting on a prominent
   transverse fold (character of the subgenus Eurycercus s.str.). The COI
   tree also does not support separation of the subgenus E. (Bullatifrons)
   from E. (Eurycercus), while separation of E. (Teretifrons) is
   well-supported. So, we propose to avoid a separation of E.
   (Bullatifrons) and regard all the species previously placed there as
   belonging to the subgenus E. (Eurycercus) emend. nov. We also
   demonstrated that E. macracanthus, E. pompholigodes, E. longirostris and
   E. nipponica have much broader distributional ranges than previously
   known.
C1 Bekker, Eugeniya I.; A.N. Severtsov Institute of Ecology and Evolution,
   Leninsky Prospect 33, Moscow 119071, Russia, Russia.
EM evbekker@ya.ru
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Key; Genetics; Evolution; Ecology; Land zones; Nearctic
   region; North America; USA
DE Eurycercus (Eurycercus) [Molecular genetics / Molecular phylogeny /
   systematics] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Ecology /  / ] [Land zones / Holarctic /
   Key to species] [ /  / distribution]. 
   Eurycercus (Eurycercus) beringi [Alaska /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Branchiopoda, Cladocera
OR Eurycercus (Eurycercus) - Baird 1843 (Cladocera): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   8; Key to species, Holarctic, Adult parthenogenetic females, p. 32]. 
   Eurycercus (Eurycercus) beringi (Cladocera): [Sp nov, Alaska, P. 28]. 
   Eurycercus (Eurycercus) longirostris - Hann 1982 (Cladocera): [Syn nov,
   Eurycercus (Eurycercus) vernalis Hann 1982, p. 24]. 
   Eurycercus (Eurycercus) macracanthus - Frey 1973 (Cladocera): [Emended

PT J
AN ZOOR14804030742
DT Article
TI A new species of sand racer, Psammodromus (Squamata: Lacertidae), from
   the Western Iberian Peninsula.
AU Fitze, Patrick S. (Patrick.Fitze@unil.ch) 
   Gonzalez-Jimena, Virginia
   San-Jose, Luis M.
   San Mauro, Diego
   Zardoya, Rafael
SO Zootaxa
VL 3205
PS 41-52
PD 24 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3205.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03205p052.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of lacertid lizard of the genus Psammodromus is described
   from the Iberian Peninsula. Genetic and recently published phenotypic
   data support the differentiation of Psammodromus hispanicus into three,
   and not as previously suggested two, distinct lineages. Age estimates,
   lineage allopatry, the lack of mitochondrial and nuclear haplotype
   sharing between lineages, ecological niche divergence, and the current
   biogeographic distribution, indicated that the three lineages correspond
   to three independent species. Here, we describe a new species,
   Psammodromus occidentalis sp. n., which is genetically different from
   the other sand racers and differentiated by the number of femoral pores,
   number of throat scales, snout shape, head ratio, green nuptial
   coloration, and number of supralabial scales below the subocular scale.
   We also propose to upgrade the two previously recognized subspecies,
   Psammodromus hispanicus hispanicus Fitzinger, 1826 from central Spain
   and Psammodromus hispanicus edwardsianus (Duges, 1829) from eastern
   Spain, to the species level: Psammodromus hispanicus stat. nov. and
   Psammodromus edwardsianus stat. nov. Given that the holotype of
   Psammodromus hispanicus was lost, we designate a neotype. We also
   analysed museum specimens of P. blanci, P. microdactylus and P. algirus
   to describe differentiation of the Psammodromus hispanicus
   lineages/species from their closest relatives.
C1 Fitze, Patrick S.; Department of Biodiversity and Evolutionary Biology,
   Museo Nacional de Ciencias Naturales (MNCN-CSIC), 28006 Madrid, Spain,
   Spain.
EM Patrick.Fitze@unil.ch
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Taxonomy; Status;
   Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Psammodromus hispanicus [Nucleic acids / DNA sequences / systematics]
   [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny / Molecular phylogeny / ] [Spain /
    / ]. 
   Psammodromus occidentalis [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Lacertidae
OR Psammodromus edwardsianus - (Duges 1829) (Lacertidae): [Raised from,
   Psammodromus hispanicus edwardsianus, p. 51]. 
   Psammodromus hispanicus - Fitzinger 1826 (Lacertidae): [Neotype
   designated, P. 46]. 
   Psammodromus hispanicus edwardsianus - (Duges 1829) (Lacertidae):
   [Raised to, Psammodromus edwardsianus, p. 51]. 
   Psammodromus occidentalis (Lacertidae): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 47].

DT Article
TI First record of Prionocrangon Wood Mason & Alcock, 1891 (Crustacea:
   Decapoda: Caridea: Crangonidae) in the East Pacific and description of a
   new species from western Mexico.
AU Hendrickx, Michel E. (michel@ola.icmyl.unam.mx) 
   Ayon-Parente, Manuel
SO Zootaxa
VL 3205
PS 63-68
PD 24 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3205.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03205p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the rare genus Prionocrangon is described from the
   central Gulf of California, Mexico. This is the first record for this
   genus of Crangonidae in the east Pacific which is otherwise widely
   distributed in the Atlantic, Pacific and Indian oceans. Prionocrangon
   incisum sp. nov. differs from all other known species of Prionocrangon
   by the presence of a deep notch near the posteroventral margin of the
   sixth abdominal somite. Presence of post-embryonic larvae in one partly
   spent female indicates that P. incisum sp. nov. exhibits abbreviated
   larval development.
C1 Hendrickx, Michel E.; Laboratorio de Invertebrados Bentonicos, Unidad
   Academica Mazatlan, Instituto de Ciencias del Mar y Limnologia,
   Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico, P.O. Box 811, Mazatlan,
   Sinaloa, 82000, Mexico, Mexico.

TI A new species of Coleodactylus Parker, 1926 (Squamata:
   Sphaerodactylidae) from the Atlantic Forest of northeast Brazil.
AU Goncalves, Ubiratan
   Torquato, Selma (selmatorquato@gmail.com) 
   Skuk, Gabriel
   Sena, George de Araujo
SO Zootaxa
VL 3204
PS 20-30
PD 23 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3204.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03204p030.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new species, Coleodactylus elizae sp. nov., is described for the
   Atlantic Forest of Northeastern Brazil. It is distinguished from other
   Coleodactylus species by the following character combinations: one
   nearly completely divided or two rostral scales, dorsal scales smooth
   and four scales forming the ungual sheath. The color pattern consists of
   white spots distributed over a pinkish background. Coleodactylus elizae
   sp. nov. is a forest species inhabiting bromeliads.

TI A new species of Parapercis (Teleostei: Pinguipedidae) from Madagascar.
AU Sparks, John S.
   Baldwin, Zachary H. (zbaldwin@amnh.org) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3204
PS 31-39
PD 23 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3204.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03204p039.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of sandperch is described from the shallow nearshore reefs
   of the Masoala Peninsula, northeastern Madagascar. The new species is
   distinguished from congeners occurring in the region by a unique
   pigmentation pattern on the caudal fin comprising two large, oblong
   black blotches, with the smaller of the two markings located dorsally
   near the fin base and a much larger and more elongate patch situated
   ventrally, as well as the presence of numerous smaller black blotches
   forming two to three bands distally on the caudal membrane, two
   longitudinal series of six to nine prominent black blotches on the mid
   and lower flank, and the presence of large diffuse dark brown blotches
   on the snout, lips, cheek and opercle.

   Street, New York, New York 10024, USA, USA.

PT J
AN ZOOR14805038819
DT Article
TI The genera of Pleurobemini (Bivalvia: Unionidae: Ambleminae).
AU Campbell, David C. (pleuronaia@gmail.com) 
   Lydeard, Charles
SO American Malacological Bulletin
VL 30
IS 1
PS 19-38
PD Feb 22 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB The unionid tribe Pleurobemini is diverse but poorly-understood
   phylogenetically. Current classification recognizes two highly diverse
   genera, Elliptio Rafinesque, 1819 and Pleurobema Rafinesque, 1820,
   besides the moderately diverse Fusconaia Simpson, 1900, and several
   genera with one to three species. However, classification at the species
   and genus level has been problematic. Molecular data and re-examination
   of shell morphology and anatomy indicate new groupings of these taxa.
   Several genera proposed by early workers such as Rafinesque and Swainson
   are available, but are poorly-characterized and are often overlooked. We
   analyzed two mitochondrial genes, cox1 and nod1, for 50 species assigned
   to Pleurobemini, including the type species of each genus and as many
   other species as possible. Although the majority of studied species in
   Elliptio, Pleurobema, and Fusconaia show close affinities to the
   respective type species, the affinities of others are problematic.
   Genera or subgenera such as Eurynia Rafinesque, 1819, Sintoxia
   Rafinesque, 1820, and Pleuronaia Frierson, 1927, generally regarded as
   subjective synonyms, apply to some clades. Other clades or unaffiliated
   species have no available name. Quincuncina burkei (Walker, 1922), the
   type of the genus Quincuncina Ortmann, 1922, is assigned to Fusconaia
   Simpson, 1900. Fusconaia apalachicola (Williams and Fradkin, 1999), F.
   therms (Lea, 1831), F. rotulata (Wright, 1899) (also listed as Obovaria
   rotulata), F. succissa (Lea, 1852), Cyclonaias tuberculatus (Rafinesque,
   1820), Uniomerus Conrad, 1853, and the Quincuncina infucata (Conrad,
   1834) complex are all excluded from Pleurobemini. The first three are
   placed in the new genus Reginaia Campbell and Lydeard; Uniomerus Conrad,
   1853 is assigned to Quadrulini; and the remainder belong in the
   pustulosa Lea, 1831 group of Quadrulini (genus Rotundaria Rafinesque,
   1820).
C1 Campbell, David C.; Paleontol Res Inst, 1259 Trumansburg Rd, Ithaca, NY,
   14850, USA, USA.
EM pleuronaia@gmail.com
RI Campbell, David/AAT-8745-2020
SC Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 0740-2783
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Biochemistry; Genetics;
   Evolution
DE Pleurobemini [Nucleic acids / mtDNA sequence variation / taxonomic
   implications] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Palaeoheterodonta, Unionoida, Unionoidea
OR Canthyria - Swainson 1840 (Unionoidea): [Junior synonym, Of Elliptio
   Rafinesque 1819, p. 28]. 
   Cunicula - Swainson 1840 (Unionoidea): [Junior synonym, Of Elliptio
   Rafinesque 1819, p. 28]. 
   Elliptio - Rafinesque 1819 (Unionoidea): [Senior synonym, Of Canthyria
   Swainson 1840, p. 28; Senior synonym, Of Cunicula Swainson 1840, p. 28;
   Senior synonym, Of Ensinaia Starbogatov 1970, p. 28]. 
   Ensinaia - Starbogatov 1970 (Unionoidea): [Junior synonym, Of Elliptio
   Rafinesque 1819, p. 28]. 
   Eurynia - Rafinesque 1820 (Unionoidea): [Status, P. 28]. 
   Fusconaia apalachicola - (Williams & Fradkin 1999) (Unionoidea):
   [Referred to, New genus Reginaia, p. 31]. 
   Fusconaia rotutulata - (Wright 1899) (Unionoidea): [Referred to, New
   genus Reginaia, p. 31]. 
   Luteacarnea - Frierson 1927 (Unionoidea): [Type species, Designated as
   Unio cooperianus Lea 1834, p. 29]. 
   Pleurobemini (Unionoidea). 
   Pleuronaia - Frierson 1927 (Unionoidea): [Spelling, P. 30; Status, P.
   30]. 
   Pleuronia - Frierson 1927 (Unionoidea): [Spelling, P. 30]. 
   Reginaia (Unionoidea): [Gen nov, Of tribe Pleurobemini, Type species
   Unio ebenus Lea 1831, p. 31]. 
   Reginaia apalachicola - (Williams & Fradkin 1999) (Unionoidea): [Comb
   nov, Transferred from Fusconaia, p. 31]. 
   Reginaia ebenus - (Lea 1831) (Unionoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Unio, p. 31]. 
   Reginaia rotulata - (Wright 1899) (Unionoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Fusconaia, p. 31]. 
   Sintoxia - Rafinesque 1820 (Unionoidea): [Status, P. 30]. 
   Striata - Frierson 1927 (Unionoidea): [Type species, Designated as Unio
   cooperianus Lea 1834, p. 30]. 
   Unio cooperianus - Lea 1934 (Unionoidea): [Designated type species for,
   Luteacarnea Frierson 1927, p. 29; Designated type species for, Striata
   Frierson 1927, p. 30]. 
   Unio ebenus - Lea 1831 (Unionoidea): [Designated type species for new
   genus, Reginaia, p. 31]. 
   Uniopsis - Swainson 1840 (Unionoidea): [Status, P. 32]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14805038819

DT Article
TI A revision of the living Mactridae (Bivalvia: Autobranchia) from
   Northern Argentina and Uruguay.
AU Signorelli, Javier H. (jsignorelli@cenpat.edu.ar) 
   Pastorino, Guido
SO American Malacological Bulletin
VL 30
IS 1
PS 85-101
PD Feb 22 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Living bivalves of the family Mactridae from Northern Argentina and
   Uruguay are herein revised. A bibliographical research yielded 22
   nominal species reported from this area. Material from several
   institutions as well as fieldwork from La Paloma, Uruguay to San Bias,
   Argentina was studied. In addition, all type material were illustrated
   and redescribed. Descriptions of the soft and hard parts including
   ultrastructure of the shell, hinge and ligament using the Scanning
   electronic microscope (SEM) were carried out. We consider Mactra guidoi
   Signorelli and Scarabino, 2010, Mactra isabelleana d'Orbigny, 1846,
   Mactra marplatensis Doello-Jurado, 1949, Mactra petitii d'Orbigny, 1846,
   Mactrella janeiroensis (Smith, 1915), Raeta plicatella (Lamarck, 1818)
   and Darina solenoides (King, 1832) as valid species. In addition, a list
   of synonyms as well as the corroborated distribution is proposed for
   each species.

DT Article
TI Revision of the genus Pazinotus (Gastropoda, Muricidae) from Brazil.
AU Santos Costa, Paulo Marcio
   Pimenta, Alexandre Dias (adpimenta@yahoo.com.br) 
SO American Malacological Bulletin
VL 30
IS 1
PS 117-126
PD Feb 22 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A revision of the genus Pazinotus from Brazil revealed the occurrence of
   three species: Pazinotus stimpsonii (Dall, 1889a), with a wide
   geographical range in the western Atlantic, including Florida, the
   Caribbean, and the southeast coast of Brazil; Pazinotus bodarti (Costa,
   1993), restricted to the southeast coast of Brazil; and Pazinotus gilt
   new species, restricted to the Canopus Bank on the northeast coast of
   Brazil. Pazinotus gilt new species is distinguished by its smaller size,
   less-pronounced teeth on the outer lip, and the absence of spiral
   sculpture on the teleoconch whorls. A microscopic sculpture is described
   for species of Pozinotus, consisting of microgranules on the protoconch
   and series of spiral pitted lines on the teleoconch surface or in the
   intritacalx of Pazinotus gill new species.
C1 Pimenta, Alexandre Dias; Departamento de Invertebrados, Museu Nacional,
   Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Quinta da Boa Vista, Sao
   Cristovao, CEP 20940-040, Rio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil,
   Brazil.
EM adpimenta@yahoo.com.br

DT Article
TI Revision of Flabelligera Sars, 1829 (Polychaeta: Flabelligeridae).
AU Salazar-Vallejo, Sergio I. (ssalazar@ecosur.mx) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 3203
PS 1-64
PD 22 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3203.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03203p064.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Flabelligera Sars, 1829 is the type genus for Flabelligeridae de
   Saint-Joseph, 1894 and includes species common in temperate or cold
   waters in the world oceans. Together with Flabelliderma Hartman, 1969
   they are the only genera whose neurohooks have multiarticulate handles
   and bending crests. However, Flabelliderma species differ because they
   form large notopodial lobes, and often have dorsal sediment tubercles.
   The revision of all type and non-type materials resulted in the
   distinction of five body patterns within Flabelligera; they can be
   recognized on the basis of body shape, tunic development, parapodial
   position, notopodial alignment, and shape of neurohooks. Flabelligera is
   restricted and four genera are proposed: Annenkova (neurohooks with
   crests tapered, apparently segmented), Flabegraviera (notopodia in
   laterally descending series, notochaetae and neurochaetae in cylindrical
   sheaths, markedly longer than body width), Flabehlersia(body fusiform,
   notopodia ventrolateral) and Flabesymbios (body papillae not covered by
   tunic, notopodia dorsal with papillae in fan-shaped pattern, neuropodia
   ventral). Flabelligera contains 16 species with three newly described
   and a replacement name is proposed: F. haswelli n. n. pro F. affine
   Haswell, F. nuniezi n. sp. from the Northeastern Atlantic and
   Mediterranean Sea, F. orensanzi n. sp. from the Southwestern Atlantic,
   and F. salazarae n. sp. from the Eastern tropical Pacific. Annenkova is
   monotypic: A. mastigophora (Annenkova, 1952) n. comb. from the
   Northwestern Pacific. Flabegraviera contains F. mundata (Gravier, 1906)
   n. comb. and F. profunda n. sp. both from the Antarctic. Flabehlersia
   includes two species: F. induta (Ehlers, 1897) n. comb. from Tierra del
   Fuego and F. persimilis (Annenkova-Chlopina 1924) n. comb. from the
   Northwestern Pacific. Flabesymbios contains two species living on
   Northeastern Pacific sea-urchins: F. commensalis (Moore, 1909) n. comb.
   on Strongylocentrotus and F. roberti n. sp. on Centrostephanus.
C1 Salazar-Vallejo, Sergio I.; Departamento de Ecologia Acuatica, El
   Colegio de la Frontera Sur, CONACYT, Apdo. Postal 424, Chetumal,
   Quintana Roo, 77000, Mexico, Mexico.

DT Article
TI Sub-seasonal oxygen and carbon isotope variations in shells of modern
   Radix sp (Gastropoda) from the Tibetan Plateau: potential of a new
   archive for palaeoclimatic studies.
AU Taft, Linda (linda.taft@fu-berlin.de) 
   Wiechert, Uwe
   Riedel, Frank
   Weynell, Marc
   Zhang, Hucai
SO Quaternary Science Reviews
VL 34
PS 44-56
PD Feb 21 2012
PY 2012
LA English
U1 1
U2 40
AB Carbon and oxygen isotope ratios have been measured for nine aragonite
   shells of the gastropod genus Radix from the lake Bangda Co (30[
   degree]29'N, 97[degree]04'E, 4450 m a.s.l.) at the south-eastern edge
   and from two characteristic sites at the lake Kyaring Co
   (31[degree]09'N, 88[degree]17'E, 4650 m a.s.l.) on the central Tibetan
   Plateau. Radix shells were sampled for isotope ratio analysis with high
   spatial resolution along the ontogenetic spiral of growth providing the
   basis of isotope records with a sub-seasonal time-resolution. [delta]18O
   values of shells from Bangda Co are on average [approximately]-15.0[per
   mill] relative to PDB and the pattern exhibits a clear onset and
   progression of the summer monsoon precipitation indicated by a strong
   "amount effect". This pattern mirrors the precipitation pattern in the
   respective year and region as expected for a small (surface area ca 0.3
   km2) and shallow (<5 m) lake or habitat with short water residence times
   and little evaporative 18O enrichment of the lake water. In contrast,
   [delta]18O values of Radix shells from Kyaring Co habitat A which is
   connected to the deep (several tens of metres) and big (surface area ca
   660 km2) lake, average at [approximately]-13.0[per mill] consistent with
   a higher evaporation rate and longer water residence time. The latter is
   supported by more 18O enriched water in this habitat. The [delta]18O
   values of Radix shells from Kyaring Co habitat B are nearly as low as
   shells from Bangda Co due to the similar habitat characteristic but
   isotopic patterns of these shells exhibit a weaker "amount effect". In
   both lake systems [delta]13C values of the shells are coupled with
   oxygen isotopes because a large amount of isotopically light carbon is
   washed from mountain slopes into the lake during the rainy season.
   Although other processes influence the isotopic patterns, e.g.
   biological productivity ([delta]13C) or temperature ([delta]18O), these
   influences are minor compared with the monsoon signal or the effect of
   evaporation in the Radix shell records. The overall weaker amount effect
   in Radix shells from Kyaring Co habitat B compared with shells from
   Bangda Co are consistent with a current decreasing monsoon influence
   from the south-eastern edge towards the central Tibetan Plateau. Thus,
   fossil shells of the gastropod genus Radix are a valuable archive for
   reconstructing climatic and environmental changes on the Tibetan Plateau
   and provide information about former habitat sizes and depths. (C) 2011
   Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Taft, Linda; Free Univ Berlin, Inst Geol Sci, Malteserstr 74-100,
   Berlin, D-12249, Germany, Germany.
EM linda.taft@fu-berlin.de
RI Taft, Linda/L-4570-2018
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Anatomy &Morphology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0277-3791
BD Biochemistry; Skeletal and supporting structures; Shell; Ecology; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Radix [Biochemistry / Stable isotopes / ] [Shell chemistry /  / ]
   [Environmental indicators /  / ] [Xizang / Bangda Co & Kyaring Co / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Basommatophora, Lymnaeoidea
OR Radix (Lymnaeoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14807045838
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029939
DT Article
TI A revision and phylogenetic analysis of the spider genus Aysenia
   Tullgren (Araneae: Anyphaenidae, Amaurobioidinae).
AU Gonzalez Marquez, Maria E. (mariaegm86@gmail.com) 
   Ramirez, Martin J.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3201
PS 1-26
PD 21 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3201.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03201p026.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Aysenia Tullgren includes 8 species of spiders endemic to the
   southern forests of Chile and Argentina. They have an elongated body,
   recurved posterior eye row and third legs directed forward. There are
   currently five known species of Aysenia. The study of all the specimens
   of Aysenia available in collections showed the existence of three
   undescribed species and the unknown male of A. elongata, all of which
   are here described. New geographical records are provided for all
   species, with illustrations and reviewed diagnosis for the genus and the
   previously known species. Data from the new species and the male of A.
   elongata are used to test the monophyly of the genus, its relationships
   with other genera in the family, and among its species. The phylogenetic
   analysis using cladistic methods uses observations from 264 previously
   defined characters plus three characters that arise from this study,
   scored for 104 species of Anyphaenidae.
C1 Gonzalez Marquez, Maria E.; Division of Arachnology, Museo Argentino de
   Ciencias Naturales "Bernardino Rivadavia", Av angel Gallardo 470
   (C1405DJR), Buenos Aires, Argentina, Argentina.

   Aysenia grismadoi; Aysenia huayun; Aysenia izquierdoi [Chile /  / New
   species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029942
DT Article
TI Hydrophis donaldi (Elapidae, Hydrophiinae), a highly distinctive new
   species of sea snake from northern Australia.
AU Ukuwela, Kanishka D.B.
   Sanders, Kate L.
   Frey, Bryan G.
SO Zootaxa
VL 3201
PS 45-57
PD 21 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3201.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03201p057.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB A new species of viviparous sea snake, Hydrophis donaldi sp. nov.
   (Hydrophiinae), is described from the Gulf of Carpentaria, northern
   Australia. Molecular analyses reveal this species as a deeply divergent
   lineage within the Hydrophis subgroup, and separate it from all other
   sampled taxa by fixed nucleotide substitutions at three independent
   mitochondrial and nuclear loci. The new species is assigned to Hydrophis
   based on the current morphological diagnosis of this large but pa-
   raphyletic genus, and is distinguished from all other Hydrophis species
   and closely allied genera by a combination of morphological characters
   relating to scalation, colour pattern and osteology. Using current keys
   for sea snakes, H. donaldi sp. nov. might be mistaken for H. coggeri, H.
   sibauensis or H. torquatus diadema but it is readily distinguished from
   these species by a higher number of bands on the body and tail, lower
   ventral count, strongly spinous body scales, and a wider, more rounded
   head. Sea snakes have been sampled intensively in the Gulf of
   Carpentaria due to their vulnerability to bycatch in the region's
   commercial prawn-trawl fisheries. That this highly distinctive new
   species has evaded discovery in the region until now is surprising, but
   might be explained by its habitat preferences. All known specimens of H.
   donaldi sp. nov. were found in estuarine habitats that are relatively
   poorly surveyed and are not targeted by commercial fisheries.
C1 Ukuwela, Kanishka D.B.; Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology,
   Darling Building, School of Earth and Environmental Sciences, University
   of Adelaide, Adelaid, SA 5005, Australia, Australia.
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Hydrophis donaldi [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New species].
   
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Serpentes, Elapidae
OR Hydrophis donaldi (Elapidae): [Sp nov, Australia, Queensland (marine),
   P. 48].

PT J
AN ZOOR14804029943
DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Oligodon Fitzinger, 1826 (Squamata:
   Colubridae) from Pulau Nias, Indonesia.
AU David, Patrick (pdavid@mnhm.fr) 
   Vogel, Gernot
SO Zootaxa
VL 3201
PS 58-68
PD 21 Feb 2012
PY 2012
UR http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/list/2012/3201.html
AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03201p068.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Oligodon Fitzinger, 1826, Oligodon wagneri
   sp. nov., is described on the basis of a single specimen originating
   from Nias Island, off the west coast of Sumatra, Indonesia. It differs
   from other species of the region by the combination of a constant number
   (15) of dorsal scale rows, undivided hemipenes, entire anal plate, form
   of dentition, and dorsal pattern of white crossbars alternating with
   three irregular reticulations. This new species is compared with other
   species of the Greater Sunda Islands with 15 or 17 dorsal scale rows. An
   updated checklist and key to Oligodon species of the region of Sumatra
   is provided.
C1 David, Patrick; Reptiles & Amphibiens, UMR 7205 OSEB, Departement
   Systematique et Evolution, CP 30, Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle,
   57 rue Cuvier, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France, France.
EM pdavid@mnhm.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Oligodon [Indonesia / Sumatra region / Key to species]. 
   Oligodon wagneri [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Serpentes, Colubridae
OR Oligodon - Boie 1827 (Colubridae): [Diagnostic characters, Species with
   15 dorsal scale rows at midbody, p. 63; Key to species, Indonesia,
   Sumatra region, P. 66]. 
   Oligodon wagneri (Colubridae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 59].

TI Discovered in historical collections: Two new Japalura species
   (Squamata: Sauria: Agamidae) from Yulong Snow Mountains, Lijiang
   Prefecture, Yunnan, PR China.
AU Manthey, Ulrich (Manthey.sseah@t-online.de) 
   Denzer, Wolfgang
   Mian, Hou
   Xiaohe, Wang

PS 27-48
PD 21 Feb 2012
PY 2012

AW http://www.mapress.com/zootaxa/2012/2/zt03200p048.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Several specimens from historical collections made in Yunnan (PR China)
   were found to be inconsistent with hitherto known species of Japalura.
   Two species are described as new: Japalura brevicauda spec. nov. and
   Japalura yulongensis spec. nov. Diagnostic features for the new species
   are compiled and a key to closely related species is produced. The geo-
   graphical distribution of these species is outlined and discussed.
